Take a moment to imagine a 10 year old boy you know, whether it's your own, a grandchild, or a friend's. 

Could you imagine for a moment mistaking them for a grown 20 year old man? 

Not across the street or on TV, but if you were actually holding them? If they were crying in terror like a 10 year old boy would if you had a gun drawn on him?

How is this even possible? How was it possible with little 12-year old Tamir Rice? 

It goes without saying that this never would have happened had the boy been white. But why?

There is a long history in America of denying the childhood and innocence of Black children. It was a part of the dehumanization and brutal exploitation that existed under both slavery and our version of apartheid, Jim Crow. 

But since at least the Reagan years, it's also been a central part of a deliberate political strategy to win working class white support by demonizing Black people. 

From the war on drugs (i.e. war on Black communities) to the repeated image of Black boys as 'super predators' throughout mainstream media, white America has been conditioned to see Black boys as criminals, thugs, drug dealers, and delinquents. 

As anyone but happy and carefree children.

This conscious political strategy of demonization is seeing its most naked and extreme form in Donald Trump. So explicit that it is almost ceasing to be a dog-whistle.

So make no mistake that while the cops may pull the triggers, or in this case commit immense emotional trauma, the blood is every bit as much on the hands of the politicians who have shaped the racist lens with which Black boys are seen in America.

status_message:
Here's why police officers have no place in our schools.

This six year old little girl took some candy off of a teacher's desk. 

Are you a parent? A grandparent? A decent human being with a pulse? What's on the list of appropriate responses to this?

Maybe asking her to put it back. Or sharing some with her. Or having a conversation about asking before taking something.

Not on the list? 

HANDCUFFING A LITTLE GIRL AND PUTTING HER ALONE UNDER SOME DARK STAIRS NEXT TO A BOILER FOR AN HOUR.

That's abuse, pure and simple. 

It's also racialized abuse, because we can be sure this never would have happened to a little white girl.

It's no accident that there are more police in schools with more people of color or that Black children are most likely to be targeted with severe and disproportionate responses.

This is part of America's long history of treating Black children as dangerous, immoral, or over-sexualized. Why else would they require literal policing?

But they're not - they're just kids. They don't need police with guns. They need caring, competent teachers and guidance counselors, like any child.

We need the police out of our schools now.

This disturbing reality is a reflection of the fact that the police in America - since their very inception - have been far more about racial control than crime control.

"The birth and development of the American police can be traced to a multitude of historical, legal and political-economic conditions. The institution of slavery and the control of minorities, however, were two of the more formidable historic features of American society shaping early policing. Slave patrols and Night Watches, which later became modern police departments, were both designed to control the behaviors of minorities. For example, New England settlers appointed Indian Constables to police Native Americans (National Constable Association, 1995), the St. Louis police were founded to protect residents from Native Americans in that frontier city, and many southern police departments began as slave patrols. In 1704, the colony of Carolina developed the nation's first slave patrol. Slave patrols helped to maintain the economic order and to assist the wealthy landowners in recovering and punishing slaves who essentially were considered property.

Policing was not the only social institution enmeshed in slavery. Slavery was fully institutionalized in the American economic and legal order with laws being enacted at both the state and national divisions of government. Virginia, for example, enacted more than 130 slave statutes between 1689 and 1865. Slavery and the abuse of people of color, however, was not merely a southern affair as many have been taught to believe. Connecticut, New York and other colonies enacted laws to criminalize and control slaves. Congress also passed fugitive Slave Laws, laws allowing the detention and return of escaped slaves, in 1793 and 1850. As Turner, Giacopassi and Vandiver (2006:186) remark, "the literature clearly establishes that a legally sanctioned law enforcement system existed in America before the Civil War for the express purpose of controlling the slave population and protecting the interests of slave owners. The similarities between the slave patrols and modern American policing are too salient to dismiss or ignore. Hence, the slave patrol should be considered a forerunner of modern American law enforcement."

- Victor E. Kappeler, Ph.D.

status_message:
"Not giving women their due in the conversation is even more ironic considering how many Black women are at the forefront of the various movements intended to ensure that Black lives matter. Black women feel the burn of institutionalized racism just as painfully as we do. Black lives being gunned down by the power structure affects us all; it's a public health issue that threatens our communities. If the police keep picking off members of our community, EVEN for obeying the law, what's going to be left?

We can't expect women to be at the forefront of these movements without acknowledging that they're not just there to support men, but because they also feel the same sting and same circumstances that we do.

The recent picture of Ieshia Evans, standing tall and serene while the two police officers looking as if they're prepared to face off against a gas chamber, speaks truth to this power. This Black woman from New York City came down to Baton Rouge to face off against the enemy and did it in the way only a Black woman can, often silently, but as powerfully as any man. She's there for many reasons, but mainly, because what happens to the Black community in Baton Rouge affects the community in New York City, St. Paul, Minnesota, Ferguson, Missouri, Chicago, Illinois, and anywhere else we are. The picture is powerful in that it shows the stark contrasts in demeanor and purpose. Ieshia is stoically and peacefully asserting her right to be here while the police officers are in action mode against the Black body at rest. I'd like to call it the irresistible force paradox, but we all know how that story ends. Luckily because of the circumstances, it only ends with her in jail.

But Black women are front and center to this movement because they have to be for their own good. Institutional racism affects all of us. Our community can't thrive unless Black men and women recognize and acknowledge each other in it. It's the only way to achieve real progress.
Because some cops may be gunning for Black men, but a Black woman will do." 

- Panama Jackson
